feed.subtitle: The best place to stay up-to-date with the latest Prettier news and events.

entry.title: Prettier 1.16: HTML improvements and better CRLF handling
entry.summary: This release improves HTML formatting and contains better CRLF handling, new syntax features, and fixes several bugs.

entry.title: Prettier 1.15: HTML, Vue, Angular and MDX Support
entry.summary: This release adds support for HTML, Vue, Angular and MDX. It also respects decorator position, adds an option for JSX single quotes, allows parser inference via shebang, adds support for several new syntax features, and has a few formatting tweaks.

entry.title: Prettier 1.14: YAML Support
entry.summary: This release adds YAML support, pragma (i.e. /** @prettier */) support for every language, and improves performance on large files. It also adds support for several new syntax features, and has a few formatting tweaks to make your code even prettier. âœ¨

entry.title: Prettier 1.13: Conquering the web!
entry.summary: This releases adds support for several new syntax features, formatting fixes and first-class support for working in the browser.

entry.title: Prettier 1.12: Fixes, Features, and Formatting, Oh My!
entry.summary: Hello everyone, and welcome to Prettier 1.12.0! This release contains a lot of bugfixes, formatting adjustments, new features for our plugin API, and new Markdown features.

entry.title: Prettier for PHP 0.1: First alpha release ðŸŽ‰
entry.summary: After more than 200 merged pull requests since mid December 2017, we're happy to announce the first alpha release of Prettier for PHP. In this blog post, we'd like to give a short overview of how the plugin works, its philosophy, and what to expect in the future.

entry.title: Prettier 1.11: CSS fixes and new TypeScript feature support
entry.summary:
This release features a ton of CSS formatting fixes as well as support for some new TypeScript features, in addition to some general bugfixes for other languages.

Since the last release, the Prettier website has gotten an all-new design thanks to @orta!

Facebook is ðŸ’¯% Prettier

Another exciting announcement is that all the JavaScript files in the Facebook codebase have now been converted to Prettier! What's mindblowing is that there hasn't been a concerted push to convert the codebase to Prettier, we just added the tooling in place and documentation on how to migrate a folder to Prettier and people just started converting their piece of the codebase.

In 8 months, 75% of the codebase was organically converted and last week we did a final push to convert the rest and enforce that every file from now on is using Prettier! It shows that Prettier is robust to support all the crazy edge cases you can imagine and also that it provides a lot of value given the crazy adoption rate.

entry.title: Prettier 1.10: One Year of Prettier ðŸŽ‚
entry.summary:
Happy Prettier-versary! It's pretty incredible that Prettier was only released a year ago and has already seen such a massive adoption and great number of contributors. For this special release, we're going to do a small retrospective around the project.

It's also an exciting release in itself because Prettier now has partial support for .vue files and the internals have been refactored such that there's a proper plugin API in order to support different languages!

entry.title: Prettier 1.9: JSX Fragments, EditorConfig and Arrow Parens
entry.summary: This release adds an option for arrow function parens in arguments, support for the new JSX fragment syntax (<>), support for .editorconfig files, and nice additions to our GraphQL and Markdown support.

entry.title: Prettier 1.8: Markdown Support
entry.summary: This release adds Markdown support, a new --insert-pragma flag, fixes a number of formatting issues, adds support for some new experimental operators, and improves our editor integration support.

entry.title: Prettier 1.7: JSX tweaks, Pragma, TypeScript and CSS fixes
entry.summary: This release features some bugfixes and tweaks around JSX, TypeScript, CSS, and JavaScript formatting, as well as a couple new features.

entry.title: Prettier 1.6: Config File, JSX
entry.summary: This release adds configuration file support to Prettier, as well as some significant enhancements to JSX printing.

entry.title: Prettier 1.5: GraphQL, CSS-in-JS & JSON
entry.summary: This release adds GraphQL formatting support, CSS-in-JS (including styled-components), and JSON support to Prettier.

entry.title: Prettier 1.4: TypeScript and CSS support
entry.summary: This release introduces support for TypeScript, CSS, Less, and SCSS languages to Prettier!

entry.title: Prettier 1.3
entry.summary: This post provides an update to Facebook's adoption or Prettier, outlines our progress on TypeScript, and details some of the improvements and fixes included in the 1.3.0 release of Prettier.

entry.title: Prettier 1.2
entry.summary: 1.0 is not the end of prettier, we're going to continue to work on the long tail of formatting issues in order to make it an awesome JavaScript code formatter. You should expect minor version releases like this one to change small things and edge cases but nothing major or controversial.

entry.title: Releasing Prettier 1.0
entry.summary:
This post was written by vjeux and edited by jlongster, and originally published here

We officially announced prettier over two months ago as a way to solve the problem of wasting time formatting your code. It started as an experiment but it clearly resonated with a lot of people, amassing ~7000 GitHub stars and over 100,000 monthly npm downloads in just two months.
